Program Name: Interprofessional Complex and Long-Term Care
Code: S417
Credential: Ontario College Graduate Certificate
Duration: 2 semesters
Starting Months: September
Domestic Tuition: $4,899.00 *
Location: Waterfront Campus

Context:
This Interprofessional Complex and Long-Term Care program offers the following key points:

1. Develop critical thinking and creative problem-solving skills through simulated team-based cases within a serious educational game platform and clinical placements.
2. Practise and hone skills during a 120-hour clinical placement which can be completed with an existing employer or through virtual connections.
3. Designed for individuals who want to coordinate or manage an interprofessional healthcare team and lead initiatives aimed to improve the Long-Term Care sector.
4. Earn college and university course credits.
5. The program is delivered online and on-demand, designed for working professionals with flexibility in learning options (full-time over two semesters or part-time).
6. Students need to be fully vaccinated against COVID-19 to complete clinical placements within agencies.
7. Requirement of a 120-hour clinical placement for graduation, where students can complete it with their current employer if they work in the long-term care sector or seek a career change.
8. Topics covered include working effectively as an interprofessional team member, evidence-based approach to planning and delivery of care, common age-related changes, assessing and responding to a client's health condition, principles of interprofessional care, relational care, and end-of-life care.
9. Flexible delivery options for students.
10. Clinical agency partners require students to be fully vaccinated against COVID-19 to complete clinical placements within their facilities.
file_path: scraped_pages/programpages2024/Interprofessional Complex and Long-Term Care Program (Postgraduate) S417 | George Brown College2024.txt

Context:
The George Brown College offers an Interprofessional Complex and Long-Term Care Ontario College Graduate Certificate (S417) program. This program prepares students for roles as coordinators or managers in various health-care facilities, including long-term care homes, retirement homes, complex continuing care, rehabilitation, home health services, home visiting health services, seniors' day services, hospitals, and other healthcare organizations that require interprofessional care knowledge and expertise.

Upon graduation, students may apply for advanced standing for two credits in an undergraduate degree at Toronto Metropolitan University. The program includes the following required courses:

- Semester 1: CLTC 4000 - Introduction to Gerontology (Online), CLTC 4001 - Introduction to Interprofessional Education and Care (Online), CLTC 4002 - Responsiveness to Adults with Frailty (Online), CLTC 4003 - Long-Term Care (Online), and COMM 4020 - Communication (Online).
- Semester 2: CINT 901 - Gerontology: Critical Issues and Future Trends (Online) and CINT 907 - Team Work in Community Services (Online).

This program offers laddering opportunities into additional certificate and diploma programs and provides transferable skills and credits toward other programs, such as baccalaureate degrees in nursing, health sciences management, or gerontology. Students who graduate from this program will be prepared to take on roles in various institutions that require interprofessional care knowledge and expertise.
file_path: scraped_pages/programpages2024/Interprofessional Complex and Long-Term Care Program (Postgraduate) S417 | George Brown College2024.txt

Context:
Program Offered: Community Services - Long-Term Care (CLTC)
Programs with Course Codes:
- CLTC 4004: Team Work in Community Services (Online)
- CLTC 4015: Coordination of Dementia Care (Online)
- CLTC 4016: Complex and Long-Term Care (Online)
- CLTC 4017: Capstone Field Placement (Field)

Program Learning Outcomes:
1. Advocate for client care plans as a member of an interprofessional team.
2. Communicate with clients, family members, and healthcare professionals to promote relational care and strengthen interprofessional collaborative practice.
3. Manage changes in clients' ability to interact with their environment to provide support to clients and family care needs.
4. Support long-term client care and quality of life within complex social, economic, legal, and political systems.
5. Manage changes in client conditions through the use of evidence-informed approaches, tools, and techniques to identify and address client health.
6. Integrate principles and philosophy of end-of-life (EOL) care to support clients and their families in complex and long-term care settings.

Tuition & Fees:
- Domestic Tuition for Fall 2023: $4,899.00
- Tuition for Fall 2024 (estimated): To be determined
- Financial Assistance: Approved for OSAP funding (subject to eligibility criteria)

Admission Requirements:
- Any health-related bachelor's degree, college-level diploma, or certificate.
- Health-related pathway programs.
- Equivalent work experience. (See documentation required)

Context:
The text is about an Ontario College certificate program in Health Sciences offered by George Brown College. This program is open to college and university graduates from any Health Sciences program, as well as healthcare professionals who do not have the required academic credentials. Applicants without a credential may need to provide endorsements, portfolios, resumes, and references. International documents must be evaluated by ICAS/WES. College or university credits may qualify applicants for course exemptions, and up to 75% of completed courses prior to applying can be transferred.

Domestic students should apply through Ontario Colleges, and international students need their documents evaluated by ICAS/WES. The program accepts applications from graduates of any Health Sciences program and healthcare professionals such as personal support workers, registered practical nurses, registered nurses, social service workers, community workers, dental hygienists, activation co-ordinators/gerontologists.

Transfer Credits: College or university credits may qualify applicants for course exemptions. If students have completed any of the 10 courses prior to applying for the certificate within the past three years, they can transfer up to 7.5 (75%) of these courses to the certificate.

Application: Domestic students should apply through Ontario Colleges. Contact information for the Sally Horsfall Eaton School of Nursing is 416-415-5000, ext. 2367 and nursing@georgebrown.ca. For more information about George Brown College, contact the Contact Centre at 416-415-2000 (TTY 1-877-515-5559) or long distance 1-800-265-2002.

Related programs: Practical Nursing (PN), Bachelor of Science in Nursing (B.Sc.N.), RPN Bridge to BScN (Postgraduate), Dana, Current Student, Interprofessional Complex and Long-Term Care, Ontario College Graduate Certificate.

For more information and to apply, visit the website for booking campus tours or info sessions.

Email communications: applicants need to agree to be sent email communications from George Brown College.

Contact Information: Sally Horsfall Eaton School of Nursing - 416-415-5000, ext. 2367 and nursing@georgebrown.ca, Contact Centre - 416-415-2000 (TTY 1-877-515-5559) or long distance 1-800-265-2002.
